stem: What is the correct method to attach lugs to welding cables?

choices.text: Hammer-crimp and tape
Hammer‑crimp and tape
Proper crimping/soldering per manufacturer with insulation
Twist and tie with wire
Bare copper strands under the lug without insulation

rationales.CHOICE-2: Proper crimping/soldering per manufacturer with insulation
Use proper lugs and crimp/solder tools; insulate to prevent shorts.

stem: Why should a shop air receiver/compressor be drained regularly?

choices.text: To increase humidity for welding
To remove moisture that can damage tools and processes
To cool the tank
To reduce air pressure permanently

rationales.CHOICE-2: To remove moisture that can damage tools and processes
Draining removes accumulated water that can harm tools and welding quality.

stem: Before moving a compressed gas cylinder, what should you do?

choices.text: Remove the cap for better grip
Leave the regulator installed
Install the protective cap and use a proper cart
Roll it on the floor by hand

rationales.CHOICE-3: Install the protective cap and use a proper cart
Fit the protective cap and move cylinders with approved carts—never by rolling.

stem: How should compressed gas cylinders be stored when not in use?

choices.text: Laid horizontally on the floor
Upright and secured with a chain or strap
Stacked in a corner
Freestanding; the cap prevents tipping

rationales.CHOICE-2: Upright and secured with a chain or strap
Cylinders must be upright and restrained to prevent tipping.

stem: How should oxygen and fuel gas cylinders be stored relative to each other?

choices.text: Together for convenience
Separated by distance or a non-combustible barrier
Separated by distance or a non‑combustible barrier
Mixed with oils to prevent corrosion
Stacked with timber spacers

rationales.CHOICE-2: Separated by distance or a non-combustible barrier
Oxygen must be separated from fuel gases to reduce fire risk.

stem: What should you do if a power tool’s cord insulation is damaged?

choices.text: Wrap it with tape and continue working
Use it only on GFCI-protected outlets
Tag it out and remove it from service until repaired
Flip the plug to restore the ground

rationales.CHOICE-3: Tag it out and remove it from service until repaired
Defective tools must be removed from service and tagged until properly repaired.

stem: For a long extension cord feeding a welder, which practice is best?

choices.text: Use the smallest gauge to save weight
Use a larger (heavier) gauge to minimize voltage drop
Coil the cord tightly for neatness
Run multiple lightweight cords in series

rationales.CHOICE-2: Use a larger (heavier) gauge to minimize voltage drop
Long runs need heavier‑gauge cords to limit voltage drop and heating.

stem: How should a ball-type flowmeter be positioned for an accurate reading?

choices.text: At any angle; it self-levels
choices.stem: How should a ball‑type flowmeter be positioned for an accurate reading?

choices.text: At any angle; it self‑levels
Horizontally, so the ball rolls freely
Vertically, with the tube upright
Upside down to prevent dust entry

rationales.CHOICE-3: Vertically, with the tube upright
Ball‑type flowmeters are read in a vertical position.

choices.stem: Why maintain fume extractor filters per the indicator or schedule?

choices.text: Dirty filters always improve capture
It ensures airflow and capture efficiency
It increases arc voltage
It replaces local exhaust hoods

rationales.CHOICE-2: It ensures airflow and capture efficiency
Clogged filters reduce airflow; maintenance preserves capture efficiency.

choices.stem: When using portable electric tools in damp areas, what should be used?

choices.text: Non-grounded two-prong adapters
Non‑grounded two‑prong adapters
A transformer for all tools
A GFCI-protected supply
A GFCI‑protected supply
A metal ladder as a ground

rationales.CHOICE-3: A GFCI-protected supply
GFCI protection reduces shock risk in damp or outdoor locations.

choices.stem: Before using a portable angle grinder, which check is mandatory?

choices.text: Remove the guard to access tight spots
Use any wheel that fits the arbor
Verify the guard is fitted and the wheel RPM rating meets or exceeds tool RPM
Lubricate the wheel with oil for a smoother cut

rationales.CHOICE-3: Verify the guard is fitted and the wheel RPM rating meets or exceeds tool RPM
A properly fitted guard and a wheel rated for the tool speed prevent wheel burst.

choices.stem: Why should a MIG gun nozzle be kept free of spatter?

choices.text: To increase resistance
To maintain gas coverage and reduce porosity
To decrease deposition rate
So the nozzle runs hotter

rationales.CHOICE-2: To maintain gas coverage and reduce porosity
Spatter in the nozzle disrupts gas shielding and can cause porosity.

choices.stem: Which is correct for maintaining an electrode holder?

choices.text: Minor cracks in insulation are acceptable
Jaws should be oily to reduce sticking
Insulation must be intact and jaws clean with no exposed conductors
Cool the holder in water after heavy use

rationales.CHOICE-3: Insulation must be intact and jaws clean with no exposed conductors
Sound insulation and clean jaws prevent shock and overheating.

choices.stem: Which finding requires removing an oxy-fuel hose from service?
Which finding requires removing an oxy‑fuel hose from service?

choices.text: Minor surface dust
Proper color coding
Blistering, cuts, or dry rot
Hose length over 15 m

rationales.CHOICE-3: Blistering, cuts, or dry rot
Hoses with cuts, blisters, or rot must be replaced.

choices.stem: Between uses, low-hydrogen electrodes (e.g., E7018) should be:
Between uses, low‑hydrogen electrodes (e.g., E7018) should be:

choices.text: Stored open to shop air to cool
Kept in a heated rod oven or sealed container per manufacturer
Dipped in water to remove dust
Left on the workbench

rationales.CHOICE-2: Kept in a heated rod oven or sealed container per manufacturer
Dry, heated storage prevents moisture pickup and hydrogen cracking.

choices.stem: Which is correct regarding welder power source ventilation?

choices.text: Block vents to keep dust out
Place the machine against a wall to save space
Keep inlet/outlet vents clear of obstructions
Cover the fan guard during welding

rationales.CHOICE-3: Keep inlet/outlet vents clear of obstructions
Adequate airflow is needed to cool internal components.

choices.stem: A sign that a GMAW gun liner may need replacement is:

choices.text: Exceptionally smooth wire feed
Increased feeding resistance and birdnesting
Higher gas flow
Lower duty cycle

rationales.CHOICE-2: Increased feeding resistance and birdnesting
Drag from a worn/dirty liner can cause feeding issues and birdnesting.

choices.stem: How should oxy-fuel connections be checked for leaks after assembly?
How should oxy‑fuel connections be checked for leaks after assembly?

choices.text: With a match
By smell only
With a leak-detecting (soapy) solution
With a leak‑detecting (soapy) solution
By touching the joints

rationales.CHOICE-3: With a leak-detecting (soapy) solution
Use a leak‑detecting solution; never use flame to check for leaks.

choices.stem: What should be avoided around welder cooling fans?

choices.text: Keeping the area clear
Blocking the intake to reduce noise
Placing rags over the guard
Stacking boxes near vents

rationales.CHOICE-2: Blocking the intake to reduce noise
Obstructions at the fan/vents can cause overheating and failure.

choices.stem: What should be done with a regulator that has a cracked or missing gauge lens?

choices.text: Use it carefully until a replacement arrives
Cover it with tape
Remove from service and have it repaired or replaced
Turn the gauge to face away from people

rationales.CHOICE-3: Remove from service and have it repaired or replaced
Damaged regulators must be removed from service and repaired or replaced.

choices.stem: Before mounting a new bonded grinding wheel, which check is recommended?

choices.text: Spin it up on the grinder at full speed
Perform a ring test and inspect for cracks
Soak the wheel in oil for cooling
Tap the wheel with a metal hammer as hard as possible

rationales.CHOICE-2: Perform a ring test and inspect for cracks
A ring (sound) test and visual inspection help detect hidden cracks before use.

choices.stem: What is an appropriate use of anti-spatter compound?
What is an appropriate use of anti‑spatter compound?

choices.text: Inside the gas diffuser
On regulator threads
Lightly on nozzles/fixtures per manufacturer’s guidance
On the contact tip bore

rationales.CHOICE-3: Lightly on nozzles/fixtures per manufacturer’s guidance
Used correctly on nozzles/fixtures, anti‑spatter helps reduce buildup.

choices.stem: To ensure a good return path, the work clamp should be attached to:

choices.text: Painted surface near the weld
Rusty scale far from the weld
Clean bare metal near the weld area
Any spot; current finds its way

rationales.CHOICE-3: Clean bare metal near the weld area
Clamp to clean, bare metal close to the weld to reduce resistance and arc blow.

choices.stem: Why should welding work leads and connections be tight and clean?

choices.text: Loose leads improve arc stability
Painted contact surfaces reduce spatter
They reduce voltage drop and overheating at the connections
Smaller cable always saves weight without consequences

rationales.CHOICE-3: They reduce voltage drop and overheating at the connections

choices.stem: Convert 15 CFH to L/min (round to 0.1).

choices.text: 6.2 L/min
7.1 L/min
8.0 L/min
9.5 L/min

rationales.CHOICE-2: 7.1 L/min

choices.stem: Convert 35 CFH to L/min (round to 0.1).

choices.text: 13.2 L/min
16.5 L/min
18.4 L/min
22.0 L/min

rationales.CHOICE-2: 16.5 L/min

choices.stem: An angle grinder is rated at 11,000 rpm. Which wheel rating is safe?

choices.text: 11,000 rpm or higher
Any, if you remove the guard

rationales.CHOICE-3: 11,000 rpm or higher

choices.stem: An angle grinder is rated at 12,000 rpm. Available wheels: 10,000 rpm and 13,300 rpm. Which should you choose?

choices.text: 10,000 rpm — it'll be fine for short cuts
13,300 rpm — meets/exceeds tool speed
Either, if using light pressure
10,000 rpm, but wear thin gloves

rationales.CHOICE-2: 13,300 rpm — meets/exceeds tool speed

choices.stem: A wire diameter of 0.035" is approximately how many millimeters (to 0.01)?
Convert 0.9 mm to inches (to 0.001").
For 0.035" GMAW wire, which contact tip size (standard fit) should be used?

choices.text: Any — it’s not critical

choices.stem: A long extension cord must supply a welder (high current). Which choice best minimizes voltage drop?

choices.text: AWG14 (thin)
AWG12
AWG10
AWG8 (thickest listed)

choices.stem: Convert 22 CFH to L/min (round to 0.1).

choices.text: 9.8 L/min
10.4 L/min
11.6 L/min
12.9 L/min

rationales.CHOICE-2: 10.4 L/min

choices.stem: Convert 28 CFH to L/min (round to 0.1).

choices.text: 11.9 L/min
13.2 L/min
14.1 L/min
15.3 L/min

rationales.CHOICE-2: 13.2 L/min

choices.stem: You need to move a gas cylinder to another area. Which sequence is correct?

choices.text: Leave the regulator on, remove the cap, and roll it on the rim
Remove the regulator, install the protective cap, secure it, and move with a cylinder cart
Carry it horizontally with two people
Pull it by the valve for better control

rationales.CHOICE-2: Remove the regulator, install the protective cap, secure it, and move with a cylinder cart

choices.stem: After assembling oxy-fuel equipment, the best set of steps to check for leaks is:

choices.text: Use a small flame — leaks will show quickly
Open valves per procedure, apply leak-detecting/soapy solution to joints, look for bubbles, fix leaks, and re-check
Rely on smell only
Tighten with a pipe wrench by feel

rationales.CHOICE-2: Open valves per procedure, apply leak-detecting/soapy solution to joints, look for bubbles, fix leaks, and re-check

choices.stem: A tool’s line cord insulation is damaged. Your action:

choices.text: Wrap with tape and finish the job
Tag out, remove from service, and send for repair/replacement
Use only with a GFCI — that’s enough
Suspend the cord overhead and continue

rationales.CHOICE-2: Tag out, remove from service, and send for repair/replacement

choices.stem: You need to mount a new wheel on a grinder and start work. Choose the correct sequence:

choices.text: Remove the guard; mount any wheel; run at full speed
Inspect the wheel → ring test → confirm wheel rating ≥ tool rpm → install with guard → start while standing to the side and check for runout
Oil the wheel for a smoother cut → run without a guard
Pick a wheel rated below tool rpm for light work

rationales.CHOICE-2: Inspect the wheel → ring test → confirm wheel rating ≥ tool rpm → install with guard → start while standing to the side and check for runout

choices.stem: Porosity appears during GMAW; the nozzle is visibly clogged with spatter. Best plan:

choices.text: Double the voltage
Stop; clean nozzle/diffuser; verify gas type/flow and no leaks; check contact tip/liner; then run a test bead
Switch to a larger wire size
Turn gas flow to zero

rationales.CHOICE-2: Stop; clean nozzle/diffuser; verify gas type/flow and no leaks; check contact tip/liner; then run a test bead

choices.stem: Portable fume extractor shows low airflow; filter indicator is in the red. What should you do?

choices.text: Ignore it — at least it’s quiet
Stop work, service/replace the filter as specified, verify capture at the working distance
Place a fan near your face
Increase welding current to ‘burn through’

rationales.CHOICE-2: Stop work, service/replace the filter as specified, verify capture at the working distance

choices.stem: Arc is unstable with signs of arc blow; the work clamp is on a painted area far from the weld. Your fix:

choices.text: Do nothing — this is normal
Move the clamp to clean bare metal close to the weld and ensure a solid contact
Spray anti-spatter on the clamp
Increase travel speed

rationales.CHOICE-2: Move the clamp to clean bare metal close to the weld and ensure a solid contact

choices.stem: Wire ‘birdnesting’ occurs at the feeder. Likely cause and action:

choices.text: Lack of shielding gas — raise the flow
Worn/dirty liner and/or wrong drive roll pressure — replace/clean the liner and adjust the rolls
Lens too dark — change filter shade
Remove the contact tip and weld without it

rationales.CHOICE-2: Worn/dirty liner and/or wrong drive roll pressure — replace/clean the liner and adjust the rolls

choices.stem: How should anti-spatter be used correctly?

choices.text: Apply generously inside the gas diffuser
Lightly on nozzles/fixtures; avoid inside the diffuser and on regulator threads
Coat the contact tip bore
Spray the welder case for easier cleanup

rationales.CHOICE-2: Lightly on nozzles/fixtures; avoid inside the diffuser and on regulator threads

choices.stem: A ball flowmeter reads erratically; it’s mounted at an angle. What should you do?

choices.text: Nothing — trust the average reading
Mount the tube vertically and readjust the flow
Shut off shielding gas for consistency
Add oil inside the tube

rationales.CHOICE-2: Mount the tube vertically and readjust the flow

choices.stem: At power cable lugs you see darkening/melted insulation, scorch marks, and odor. Your actions?

choices.text: Continue until it gets worse
Stop, de-energize, tag out; disassemble; clean contact faces to bare metal; replace damaged lugs/cable; reassemble to proper torque; then load-test and check heat/voltage drop
Wrap tightly with tape and retighten without disassembly
Cool with water and continue

rationales.CHOICE-2: Stop, de-energize, tag out; disassemble; clean contact faces to bare metal; replace damaged lugs/cable; reassemble to proper torque; then load-test and check heat/voltage drop

choices.stem: One cable lug runs much hotter than others and there’s a burning smell. What should your diagnosis focus on?

choices.text: Measure voltage drop under load at that lug and compare to others; verify torque/clean contact; replace parts if needed
Measure only open-circuit voltage; if normal, ignore
Reduce current and paint the area with high-temp paint
Apply grease to conductive faces

rationales.CHOICE-1: Measure voltage drop under load at that lug and compare to others; verify torque/clean contact; replace parts if needed

choices.stem: What is the correct way to assess voltage drop on a long welding lead?

choices.text: Measure cable resistance with an ohmmeter only (no load)
Compare voltage at the power source vs. at the torch/holder while welding (under load); also monitor cable/connection temperature
Judge by arc color
If lugs don’t spark, there’s no drop

rationales.CHOICE-2: Compare voltage at the power source vs. at the torch/holder while welding (under load); also monitor cable/connection temperature

choices.stem: The work clamp is getting hot and sparking. Best sequence:

choices.text: Spray anti-spatter on the clamp
Clean to bare metal, reposition close to the weld, ensure firm contact; replace worn clamp; check cable integrity and fasteners
Increase shielding gas flow
Ignore — this is normal at high current

rationales.CHOICE-2: Clean to bare metal, reposition close to the weld, ensure firm contact; replace worn clamp; check cable integrity and fasteners

choices.stem: At a bolted splice between welding leads you see oxide/green corrosion and loose hardware. What is correct?

choices.text: Just tighten the bolt without disassembly
De-energize; disassemble; clean contacts; replace washers/bolt if needed; reassemble per spec (flat/lock washers), torque to spec; protect from corrosion; verify under load
Spray with penetrating oil and keep working
Add extra insulation over the corrosion

rationales.CHOICE-2: De-energize; disassemble; clean contacts; replace washers/bolt if needed; reassemble per spec (flat/lock washers), torque to spec; protect from corrosion; verify under load

choices.stem: A copper cable is terminated on an aluminum bus with a standard copper lug; local overheating is evident. Correct remedy:

choices.text: Apply graphite grease on the joint
Use a bimetallic transition lug/pad and rebuild per instructions; replace damaged parts
Double the torque
Paint the area with high-temp coating

rationales.CHOICE-2: Use a bimetallic transition lug/pad and rebuild per instructions; replace damaged parts

choices.stem: A welding fixture was repaired: worn locating pins replaced. What is correct for documentation and control?

choices.text: Nothing — minor repair
Record the operation in the traveler/router, update part IDs/serials, obtain hold-point sign-off if required, and check repeatability
Tell the next shift verbally
Lock the fixture until the next PM without records

rationales.CHOICE-2: Record the operation in the traveler/router, update part IDs/serials, obtain hold-point sign-off if required, and check repeatability

choices.stem: During fixture repair, an engineer proposes adding a stop (design change). Proper approach:

choices.text: Do it immediately; it’s a small tweak
Initiate MOC/ECN/ECR, get approval, update drawing/work instructions, then implement
Make the change now; document after the batch
Let the welder decide on the spot

rationales.CHOICE-2: Initiate MOC/ECN/ECR, get approval, update drawing/work instructions, then implement

choices.stem: After fixture repair, which checks are appropriate before release to production?

choices.text: None if it looks clean
Calibrate/verify key dimensions, trial assembly/weld a control sample with measurements, verify repeatability; sign off in the traveler
Cosmetic inspection only
Have a fitter sign for the inspector

rationales.CHOICE-2: Calibrate/verify key dimensions, trial assembly/weld a control sample with measurements, verify repeatability; sign off in the traveler

choices.stem: During fixture repair, clamps were replaced with a different part number. How do you maintain traceability?

choices.text: Delete old records — they’re unnecessary
Record the change in the fixture log/traveler with the new part number/lot; update the fixture list at the cell and train staff if needed
Throw old parts in an unmarked bin
Send a photo to a group chat — enough

rationales.CHOICE-2: Record the change in the fixture log/traveler with the new part number/lot; update the fixture list at the cell and train staff if needed

choices.stem: An extension cord on a reel is used at high load. Best way to lower overheating risk:

choices.text: Leave it coiled — less tangling
Fully unspool, use only needed length, choose heavier gauge, and periodically check temperature
Oil the cable for cooling
Cover it with a blanket to block drafts

rationales.CHOICE-2: Fully unspool, use only needed length, choose heavier gauge, and periodically check temperature

choices.stem: You need 40 m of reach. You have two thin 20 m cords (AWG14) and one heavy 25 m cord (AWG10). What’s preferable for a welder?

choices.text: Connect the two AWG14 cords — length achieved
Use the AWG10 cord and reposition the power source closer to reduce length
Add another thin cord for redundancy
Increase current to compensate for voltage drop

rationales.CHOICE-2: Use the AWG10 cord and reposition the power source closer to reduce length

choices.stem: Which signs indicate excessive voltage drop due to extension cords/connections?

choices.text: Unstable, ‘soft’ arc and hot plugs/receptacles/clamps
Less spatter means everything is perfect
Higher deposition at lower current
Cold cables during prolonged high load

choices.stem: Where is it most effective to place GFCI protection when feeding tools via an extension cord?

choices.text: At the source receptacle (or use a cord/box with built-in GFCI) to protect the whole run
Only at the load — cheaper
GFCI isn’t needed if the cable is thick
Anywhere — placement doesn’t matter

rationales.CHOICE-1: At the source receptacle (or use a cord/box with built-in GFCI) to protect the whole run

choices.stem: A bundle of several extension cords lies coiled in a narrow channel. How to reduce overheating risk?

choices.text: Do nothing — cable will handle it
Separate for airflow, use a single heavier-gauge cord instead of several, and remove coils/reels
Press foam board on top
Wet the bundle periodically

rationales.CHOICE-2: Separate for airflow, use a single heavier-gauge cord instead of several, and remove coils/reels
rationales.CHOICE-3: Good electrical contact minimizes resistance, heat buildup, and erratic arc behavior.
